title: Black Eyed Dreams
body:
read it on the AO3 at http://bit.ly/2X6NjGq

by itsaspnthing

You hunt with the Winchester brothers, but it is a little bit more than that. The three of you share a very intimate bond that can not and will not be broken. Sam was water, Dean was fire, and you, well you were Earth. This bond will not be broken, unless by the hand of Crowley.

Words: 2516, Chapters: 1/?, Language: English

Series: Part 1 of Black Eyed Dreams

  • Rating: Mature
  • Warnings: No Archive Warnings Apply
  • Categories: F/M
  • Characters: Reader, Dean Winchester, Sam Winchester, Crowley (Supernatural)
  • Relationships: Dean Winchester/You, Sam Winchester/You, Dean Winchester/Sam Winchester/You
  • Additional Tags: Polyamory, Multiple Partners, Dominant Dean, Dominant Sam, Submissive Reader, Fluff, Angst, Smut, Erotica, Nightmares, Gentle Sam Winchester, Cunnilingus, Protectiveness

summary: Do you think Crowley would've made an interesting "dad" to Jack? (I miss Crowley)
question: Do you think Crowley would've made an interesting "dad" to Jack? (I miss Crowley)
answer: Hmmm… personally? I don’t think he would be much of a father figure and that he would be pretty indifferent to Jack. Not that Crowley is a bad character (we all know he is secretly sweet under all the layers of grump), but he is more of an acquaintance than a family man. Would he be nice to Jack? Most likely. But probably only in a “the Winchesters and feathers would kill me if I messed up and the kid isn’t that bad” way

reblog.comment: Hmmm… personally? I don’t think he would be much of a father figure and that he would be pretty indifferent to Jack. blog.name: trans-aziraphale
blog.title: Aziraphale & Crowley are gay trans men
blog.description: Alix; 26 | trans, non-binary gentleman: they/he | bowler hat wearer | entp | unreasonable anarchist | ao3 | mixes | byf | likes books, plants, old things, & disobedient angels

tags: this is over 1000 words but still should be considered a work in progress
summary: Making An Effort: The Queer Masculinity of Ethereal and Occult Beings in Good Omens
title: Making An Effort: The Queer Masculinity of Ethereal and Occult Beings in Good Omens
body:
“[A]ngels are sexless unless they really want to make an effort.”

How should we as readers look at and understand the gender and sex of ethereal and occult beings in Good Omens? Both Aziraphale and Crowley make repeated ‘efforts’ to not only assimilate into human society but to specifically exist in the socially constructed genders of the society in which they live. More specifically they exist, live, and experience the world as men and that conscious choice should be acknowledged and respected by readers. 

I could just says ‘in this essay I will’ and leave it, but this is important to me and I actually am going to write this essay so, in this essay I will argue that both Aziraphale and Crowley make an effort to be gendered and should be considered men and more specifically, in the language of 2019, should be considered trans men. 

[edited: read the extended, expanded version of this essay here!]

Gender is socially constructed, it’s not an innate quality of a person, it requires an effort by everyone, cis, trans, and otherwise. Within a society gender exists as a complex set of rules and subtleties that are either followed or broken, performed or subverted by the individuals within that society, it requires all members of a society to make an effort. When we gender, or transgender, or ungender ourselves we are all making an effort, through our clothes, through our bodies, through our actions, etc, they’re all efforts in a particular direction.

“For those of angel stock or demon breed, size, and shape, and composition are merely options.” Aziraphale and Crowley are both full capable to altering their physical forms, their male forms are a conscious choice on their part and they have gendered their appearances and their actions enough that people around them see them and refer to them as men (and in Aziraphale’s case, a gay man). These male bodies are the bodies that they want to exist in.

Crowley’s narration explicitly calls his human male form his favorite shape after he changed into ‘something dreadful’ to scare one of the paintballers. Not only that but he says to Aziraphale that he hates doing that because he’s always afraid he’s going to forget how to change back. His form as it is, ie a man, is exceptionally important him and being taken out of it is a source of anxiety for him.

While Aziraphale’s relationship with his gender is more internalized than Crowley’s, his actions speak to the same end. Like Crowley, his physical form is a conscious choice, they can look like and be any gender and they still choose to be men. 

Angels were created wholly outside current concepts of gender and sex, they don’t don’t have a gender or sex and they don’t not have one. It’s difficult to conceptualize this because gender is so ingrained in our culture, but it’s not for angels (or Fallen angels for that matter). Religious writing generally make reference to angels taking the form of humans in an illusionary context when they speak to people. But Aziraphale clearly goes beyond that; he has chosen to exist as a (gay) man. He’s a man when he’s interacting with humans, he’s a man when he’s hanging out in the back room just with Crowley, and he doesn’t change anything when he’s sitting alone, reading, and gathering dust. He never drops any illusion, he never stops being a man. (And this I think is a difficult thing for cis people to understand, even when I’m alone in my room with no one else, I am still, in a way, consciously aware of, and performing my gender, even though there’s no one to perform to because it’s still something that I have to do.)

It is also extremely significant that everyone who meets Aziraphale assumes that he is a gay man, technically two separate assumptions that, while correct about him today, were not technically correct yet at that the moment of his creation. It’s correct now because Aziraphale’s sense of identity has changed and he’s making an effort to make it correct. 

Aziraphale’s masculinity is indivisible from his queerness, which is to say his identity is not just A Man but A Gay Man specifically. The masculinity which he has created for himself, which he performs and inhabits, is a queer one. 

His masculine identity is not what is is typically considered traditionally masculine for the culture. Shadwell describes him as soft, his hands are elegant and manicured (in 1990), he freely touches other men (again in 1990 which was a very different time) several of the homophobic insults used against him specifically invoke concepts on effeminacy. He doesn’t just default to a stereotypical masculine existence, he constructs his own masculinity based on what’s important to his concept of his own masculine identity. It’s a choice. And it’s a choice that stands in defiance of what society says, and what would be easier, and that makes it all the more significant.

He is both aware and proud of his queer masculine identity. He is aware of how humans perceive him and leans into that both individually and in collaboration with Crowley (as AJ and I recently discussed) because that’s who he is. He doesn’t change the way he performs his masculinity because of the way it’s perceived even though it would likely make his life easier (or at least, make humans less rude towards him). His queer masculinity is important to him. 

Four different slurs and insults used for gay men specifically are used against Aziraphale in the text, either for the way he dresses, the way he behaves, or the way he speaks. He is aware that these words are used against him (he’s not just A Southern Pansy, he’s THE Southern Pansy) and aware of the meaning and cruelness behind them (while he easily brushes off Warlock’s heckling of his magic, after one of Warlock’s friends calls him a f****t he decides that Warlock is ‘obviously infernally tainted’).

He is comfortable and proud of his identity as a gay man and proudly reclaims the insults people have used against him. His identity as a gay man is important to him, it matters, so much so that he does indeed ‘make an effort’, he is a man, and his identity should be acknowledged and respected as should Crowley’s. 

(Several people have felt the need to comment on a previous post that ‘sexless’ should be read as a euphemism for ‘without genitalia’. While the original intention of the line cannot be inferred by the text, it should be pointed out that if that was what was meant, that doesn’t actually change the above points. If the bodies Crowley and Aziraphale have are indeed lacking genitalia, they’re still making an effort to be exist as, and be seen as men. A man without a penis is still a man and when they make that effort to exist as and be seen as men their gender should be acknowledged and the same acknowledgement should be extended to Aziraphale and Crowley.)

But Aziraphale clearly goes beyond that; he has chosen to exist as a (gay) man. He’s a man when he’s interacting with humans, he’s a man when he’s hanging out in the back room just with Crowley, and he doesn’t change anything when he’s sitting alone, reading, and gathering dust. He never drops any illusion, he never stops being a man. (And this I think is a difficult thing for cis people to understand, even when I’m alone in my room with no one else, I am still, in a way, consciously aware of, and performing my gender, even though there’s no one to perform to because it’s still something that I have to do.)

It is also extremely significant that everyone who meets Aziraphale assumes that he is a gay man, technically two separate assumptions that, while correct about him today, were not technically correct yet at that the moment of his creation. It’s correct now because Aziraphale’s sense of identity has changed and he’s making an effort to make it correct. 

Aziraphale’s masculinity is indivisible from his queerness, which is to say his identity is not just A Man but A Gay Man specifically. The masculinity which he has created for himself, which he performs and inhabits, is a queer one. 

His masculine identity is not what is is typically considered traditionally masculine for the culture. Shadwell describes him as soft, his hands are elegant and manicured (in 1990), he freely touches other men (again in 1990 which was a very different time) several of the homophobic insults used against him specifically invoke concepts on effeminacy. He doesn’t just default to a stereotypical masculine existence, he constructs his own masculinity based on what’s important to his concept of his own masculine identity. It’s a choice. And it’s a choice that stands in defiance of what society says, and what would be easier, and that makes it all the more significant.

He is both aware and proud of his queer masculine identity. He is aware of how humans perceive him and leans into that both individually and in collaboration with Crowley (as AJ and I recently discussed) because that’s who he is. He doesn’t change the way he performs his masculinity because of the way it’s perceived even though it would likely make his life easier (or at least, make humans less rude towards him). His queer masculinity is important to him. 

Four different slurs and insults used for gay men specifically are used against Aziraphale in the text, either for the way he dresses, the way he behaves, or the way he speaks. He is aware that these words are used against him (he’s not just A Southern Pansy, he’s THE Southern Pansy) and aware of the meaning and cruelness behind them (while he easily brushes off Warlock’s heckling of his magic, after one of Warlock’s friends calls him a f****t he decides that Warlock is ‘obviously infernally tainted’).

He is comfortable and proud of his identity as a gay man and proudly reclaims the insults people have used against him. His identity as a gay man is important to him, it matters, so much so that he does indeed ‘make an effort’, he is a man, and his identity should be acknowledged and respected as should Crowley’s. 

(Several people have felt the need to comment on a previous post that ‘sexless’ should be read as a euphemism for ‘without genitalia’. While the original intention of the line cannot be inferred by the text, it should be pointed out that if that was what was meant, that doesn’t actually change the above points. If the bodies Crowley and Aziraphale have are indeed lacking genitalia, they’re still making an effort to be exist as, and be seen as men. A man without a penis is still a man and when they make that effort to exist as and be seen as men their gender should be acknowledged and the same acknowledgement should be extended to Aziraphale and Crowley.)

trail.content_raw:
“[A]ngels are sexless unless they really want to make an effort.”

How should we as readers look at and understand the gender and sex of ethereal and occult beings in Good Omens? Both Aziraphale and Crowley make repeated ‘efforts’ to not only assimilate into human society but to specifically exist in the socially constructed genders of the society in which they live. More specifically they exist, live, and experience the world as men and that conscious choice should be acknowledged and respected by readers. 

I could just says ‘in this essay I will’ and leave it, but this is important to me and I actually am going to write this essay so, in this essay I will argue that both Aziraphale and Crowley make an effort to be gendered and should be considered men and more specifically, in the language of 2019, should be considered trans men. 

[[MORE]]

[edited: read the extended, expanded version of this essay here!]

Gender is socially constructed, it’s not an innate quality of a person, it requires an effort by everyone, cis, trans, and otherwise. Within a society gender exists as a complex set of rules and subtleties that are either followed or broken, performed or subverted by the individuals within that society, it requires all members of a society to make an effort. When we gender, or transgender, or ungender ourselves we are all making an effort, through our clothes, through our bodies, through our actions, etc, they’re all efforts in a particular direction.

“For those of angel stock or demon breed, size, and shape, and composition are merely options.” Aziraphale and Crowley are both full capable to altering their physical forms, their male forms are a conscious choice on their part and they have gendered their appearances and their actions enough that people around them see them and refer to them as men (and in Aziraphale’s case, a gay man). These male bodies are the bodies that they want to exist in.

Crowley’s narration explicitly calls his human male form his favorite shape after he changed into ‘something dreadful’ to scare one of the paintballers. Not only that but he says to Aziraphale that he hates doing that because he’s always afraid he’s going to forget how to change back. His form as it is, ie a man, is exceptionally important him and being taken out of it is a source of anxiety for him.

While Aziraphale’s relationship with his gender is more internalized than Crowley’s, his actions speak to the same end. Like Crowley, his physical form is a conscious choice, they can look like and be any gender and they still choose to be men. 

Angels were created wholly outside current concepts of gender and sex, they don’t don’t have a gender or sex and they don’t not have one. It’s difficult to conceptualize this because gender is so ingrained in our culture, but it’s not for angels (or Fallen angels for that matter). Religious writing generally make reference to angels taking the form of humans in an illusionary context when they speak to people. But Aziraphale clearly goes beyond that; he has chosen to exist as a (gay) man. He’s a man when he’s interacting with humans, he’s a man when he’s hanging out in the back room just with Crowley, and he doesn’t change anything when he’s sitting alone, reading, and gathering dust. He never drops any illusion, he never stops being a man. (And this I think is a difficult thing for cis people to understand, even when I’m alone in my room with no one else, I am still, in a way, consciously aware of, and performing my gender, even though there’s no one to perform to because it’s still something that I have to do.)

It is also extremely significant that everyone who meets Aziraphale assumes that he is a gay man, technically two separate assumptions that, while correct about him today, were not technically correct yet at that the moment of his creation. It’s correct now because Aziraphale’s sense of identity has changed and he’s making an effort to make it correct. 

Aziraphale’s masculinity is indivisible from his queerness, which is to say his identity is not just A Man but A Gay Man specifically. The masculinity which he has created for himself, which he performs and inhabits, is a queer one. 

His masculine identity is not what is is typically considered traditionally masculine for the culture. Shadwell describes him as soft, his hands are elegant and manicured (in 1990), he freely touches other men (again in 1990 which was a very different time) several of the homophobic insults used against him specifically invoke concepts on effeminacy. He doesn’t just default to a stereotypical masculine existence, he constructs his own masculinity based on what’s important to his concept of his own masculine identity. It’s a choice. And it’s a choice that stands in defiance of what society says, and what would be easier, and that makes it all the more significant.

He is both aware and proud of his queer masculine identity. He is aware of how humans perceive him and leans into that both individually and in collaboration with Crowley (as AJ and I recently discussed) because that’s who he is. He doesn’t change the way he performs his masculinity because of the way it’s perceived even though it would likely make his life easier (or at least, make humans less rude towards him). His queer masculinity is important to him. 

Four different slurs and insults used for gay men specifically are used against Aziraphale in the text, either for the way he dresses, the way he behaves, or the way he speaks. He is aware that these words are used against him (he’s not just A Southern Pansy, he’s THE Southern Pansy) and aware of the meaning and cruelness behind them (while he easily brushes off Warlock’s heckling of his magic, after one of Warlock’s friends calls him a f****t he decides that Warlock is ‘obviously infernally tainted’).

He is comfortable and proud of his identity as a gay man and proudly reclaims the insults people have used against him. His identity as a gay man is important to him, it matters, so much so that he does indeed ‘make an effort’, he is a man, and his identity should be acknowledged and respected as should Crowley’s. 

(Several people have felt the need to comment on a previous post that ‘sexless’ should be read as a euphemism for ‘without genitalia’. While the original intention of the line cannot be inferred by the text, it should be pointed out that if that was what was meant, that doesn’t actually change the above points. If the bodies Crowley and Aziraphale have are indeed lacking genitalia, they’re still making an effort to be exist as, and be seen as men. A man without a penis is still a man and when they make that effort to exist as and be seen as men their gender should be acknowledged and the same acknowledgement should be extended to Aziraphale and Crowley.)
trail.content:
“[A]ngels are sexless unless they really want to make an effort.”

blog.name: orpheusetude
blog.title: Orpheusetude
blog.description:
I like books, brits, and bands. As well as wine, words and wit.

Co-founder of 221b Con, Baker Street Babe, and Cocktails and Khaki co-host.

title: My Good Omens Sexuality Rant
body:
Friendly reminder that asexuality exists.

I feel the need to point this out because I saw something today that made me kinda angry.

People are already playing the queer baiting card on amazon due to the Azi/Crowley valentine card they put out. In the various comments about this I have seen two things stand out that really really bother me.

1. People who are angry about Neil saying that Aziraphale isn’t gay and using that angels are sexless as an excuse.

This is literally what the reality would be. I know I conflate them as being gay because they are general male in presentation but legitimately they don’t have to be male, they don’t even have to present as being same sex. It would be generally much more accurate to say they are pansexual placing any sexuality they may have somewhat outside of the concept or biological sex and gender.

And the thing that really made me decide to write this:

2. I saw someone suggest that it was ridiculous to present two male characters who had had nobody but each other for thousands of years as not being together and that it only happens to make the generally straight audience comfortable.

a) they are not male characters! At least not really. And assuming biological gender based on appearance is one of those things we really need to get better about.

b) we know that Az and Crowley crossed paths often but in the book we are lead very much to believe that the constant companionship in their relationship really forms out of the time the spend working on ‘raising’ Adam. I always got the impression that while the both have feelings for each other it wasn’t something that would have been acted upon until post apocowasn’t.

c) people can have deep feelings for each other without constant displays of overt affection. Just because you don’t seem them make out on screen, something that would be totally counter to the story being told, doesn’t mean they aren’t in love. I think Michael Sheen really does have it right that Aziraphale is desperate not to let Crowley see his feelings. If they haven’t admitted the feelings to each other, or even themselves, then it wouldn’t make sense to portray them as a full on couple.

d) people seem not to consider the fact that asexual people exist and our favorite angel and demon may very well be asexual. This falls perfectly in line with Neil’s statements regarding sex. The idea that angels have to ‘make an effort’ to not be sexless speaks very much to me as someone who identifies with being ace. The can be romantically involved without physicality just as much as they could be physical with each other without being in love. 

I just feel like these constant complaints about queer baiting 

a) ignore the existence of subtext as a thing that should not have to be textually authenticated

b) ignores the concept of them being in love but not yet together and then gets angry when a story, that is not about them getting together, doesn’t show them get together

c) ignores the feelings of us asexual folks that look at a relationship like Crowley and Aziraphale and put ourselves in those shoes, hoping someday we will find someone to love like that without the pressure of sexual intimacy or performative affection.

In short, they could really fuck things up in this show, but given the actor’s comments I think it will be ok.

I think we will get plenty of the little looks and pauses that show the beginnings of romantic interest without a blatant statement of their being together or being sexually involved. 

I dunno, sorry about ranting but for the first time ever I kind felt like the commentary I was seeing was literally discounting the possibilities of an ace reading or of alternate gender readings of the characters and it really bothered me that people being upset about representation would inadvertently devalue something like that.

title: 11 inch Heroine
body:
read it on the AO3 at http://bit.ly/2GvSt9V

by Bluewingeddean

THE PLOT AND DIOLOGUE OF THE MOVIE 10 INCH HERO.
-
Dean moves to a seaside town to get away from his old life and Sams basement. He’s an artist and needs inspiration which is just what the beach can do… that and he gave his son away when he was a teenager, seeing an art award in the paper for a ‘Ben Novak’ that looks exactly like him and has the same name as his son.
He meets the father, Cas. And things hit off. Is it his son? Will they be a family? Will everything turn out how they want it?
Fluff and smutt included ;)

There are also other random relationships going on with some fun asf backstories.

-
You definitely don’t have to have seen TIH to read this, it’s probably funner and more surprise if you haven’t.
If you have it’s like wow yeah that happened in the movie
Lol
